page.title: 02THE RIVER TWEED
page.content: "The river that runs for miles" For 27 kilometres of its course the Tweed forms the boundary between England and Scotland.It rises in Scotland,at Tweedswell in the Borders region.For a while it runs northwards through the hills around Peebles now called by its traditional name of Tweeddale.It then begins to turn east and flows from Peebles across to Melrose,in a deep,wooded valley.The Tweed continues across the Borders flowing northeast through Coldstream, separating the Scottish county from Northumberland in England.It enters the North Sea at Berwick Upon Tweed which has belonged to Scotland in the past but is now in Northumberland.The Tweed is 156km long altogether.In the Borders the Tweed is important for fishing and watersports.
